Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Modeling DOC dynamics from landscapes to coasts: hydrological connectivity and estuary processes
Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit: The origin, function, and fate of dissolved organic carbon (DOC) in terrestrial ecosystems and its transport processes from landscapes to sea are only partially understood. In this proposed research, statistical and GIS-based transport models are used to study DOC dynamics in terrestrial ecosystems and rivers. The research objectives are three-fold:
1) To analyze the spatial variability of DOC contributions from land surfaces to streams at sub-basin scales.
2) To identify the transport and transformation mechanisms behind long (decades) and short (days to months) term DOC fluctuations due to natural and anthropogenic influences.
3) To predict DOC concentration from remote sensing reflectance, turbidity and chlorophyll in rivers.

In the past several years, a large amount of field data, has been collected including 5-years of monthly DOC measurements in 30 sub-basins, high spatial and temporal resolution riverine observations, and remote sensing imagery. Equipped with these data, the team will rely mainly on an approach that integrates statistical modeling and GIS-based transport modeling. Specifically, they will
1) Use an adaptive varying coefficient mixture model to derive monthly DOC loads from uniform land use types.
2) Construct a GIS-based transport model for routing DOC mass in the drainage stream network.
3) Use a varying coefficient functional linear model and nonparametric functional model to predict DOC through remote sensing
4) Validate the above models with independent data sets from two specific river watersheds.

The geosciences contribution from this project lies in the improved understanding of the DOC export processes influenced by interactions among human activities, natural events, watershed characteristics, and climate. The statistical contribution lies in the innovative estimation and inference procedures that are particularly adapted to this complex geoscience data.

Broader impacts: This proposed research will improve the scientific understanding of carbon export processes from land to coastal waters. Funding of this project will potentially change the public?s perception of the influence of their actions in coastal communities. This research will result in a modeling technique that is suitable for studying interactions among watershed properties, human activities, natural events and climate change. The project provides learning opportunities for all participating students. The methods, models, and data from this research will be integrated into undergraduate and graduate teaching programs in a broad range of disciplines (statistics, biogeochemistry, remote sensing, hydrology, and modeling). The collaboration offers students access to cutting edge modeling techniques and environmental sciences through an equal partnership of two diverse research institutions. Especially, the two female PIs will be valuable assets in guiding female graduate students to become future fellow scientists (statisticians and geo-scientists) with their own experiences. Coastal carbon research-related instructional materials will be developed and disseminated through existing educational programs and The Bridge website. These outreach efforts will strongly benefit from early experience on the COSEE-New England and Watershed-Integrated Sciences Partnership (GK-12) programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research was focused on studying the origin and fate of dissolved organic carbon (DOC) in terrestrial ecosystems and its transport processes through hydrological connectivity. Our geographic approach involves controlled experiments, field measurements, modeling integration, and satellite assessment in three spatial scales: mesocosms, sub-basins, and river watersheds. The experiments based on mesocosms were conducted for measuring changes in terrestrial DOC production rate with resident times and temperatures. The study considered deciduous and evergreen forest leaf falls, and agricultural residential scenarios plus bare soil. The experiment later was extended to examine DOC dynamics in aquatic mesocosms during transport. Three watersheds with different dominant landuses: urban, forest and agricultural, were selected to link results from mesocosms to assess DOC production, leaching and delivery ratios to nearby streams at sub-basin scales. We have incorporated the project findings from meso- and sub-basin scales into models to study the terrestrial DOC changes in response to spatial scales, land physical conditions, and climates. A part of our effort was to identify the factors driving the co-variance between DOC concentrations and the corresponding bio-optical properties of freshwaters. The resulting algorithms have been validated for rivers and lakes at regional and global scales. We present the major project outcomes and scientific findings that address the intellectual merit of our study as follows.

 

The research has resulted in three major outcomes that improved scientific understanding of the changes in terrestrial DOC production rate in response to the variations of watershed characteristics and temperatures. 1) Cumulative soil DOC production for forest leaf litters and agricultural residuals increase logarithmically with resident times (days) for the first 10 weeks. The DOC production rates from deciduous forest leaf litters are about 25% higher than that from evergreen forest and 2 fold higher than that from agricultural residuals (Figure 1). 2) Temperature influences on terrestrial DOC production exceeds the impacts of land-surface characteristics, when the variation of annual mean temperatures is large (e.g., >5 ?C) with sufficient precipitation levels (Figure 2). The percent of wetland areas had greater influences on in-stream DOC concentrations relative to all other land uses. 3) Spring snow-melt discharge multiplies the riverine DOC loading from an agricultural watershed. A hysteresis of DOC rising in the autumn storm-flow indicates low inputs from surface runoff. Extreme events in spring would cause intolerable fluxes of riverine DOC from agricultural landscapes. The proportional leverage of agricultural land usage on riverine DOC loading during storm discharges will be significantly magnified by hydro-climatic extremes at regional and global scales.

 

Our two major results are the significant contributions to the knowledge on DOC transport and the transformation mechanisms in streams and rivers. 1) Aquatic DOC concentrations were degraded linearly with resident time (days). Degradation rate of DOC produced from deciduous leaf-falls changed more rapid than that from evergreen forest and agricultural residuals (figure 3a and b). The impact of temperature on DOC degradation are noticeable, but not to a significant degree for each plant types. 2) In contrasting to degradation, DOC additions from aquatic plants (lentic sources) increased at least as fast as the productions of deciduous forest litter-falls (figure 4). These results are important in studying the autochthonous and allochthonous DOC sources of in-land waters.
